topSong.title: Try Again
topSong.recorded: January 2000; Manhattan Center , ( New York City , New York )
topSong.label: Blackground / Virgin

descr.p: "Try Again" is a Grammy-nominated single by the late American singer Aaliyah. The song went #1 on the Billboardcharts, received favorable reviews, and won several prestigious awards.

The song was written by Static Major and Tim Mosley (Timbaland) and produced by Tim Mosley. It was the second single released from the Romeo Must Diesoundtrack and written for the motion picture of the same name. The single was released to radio while "I Don't Wanna" was still at radio, "Try Again" had peaked by the time "I Don't Wanna" was phasing out. "Try Again" was one of her most successful songs on both the American charts and the international charts. It was the first song ever to reach number one on the Billboard Hot 100 based solely on the strength of its radio airplay.
The song was listed 10th on The Village Voice's 2000 Pazz & Jop critics' poll. In November 2002, NMEmagazine ranked "Try Again" #93 on their list of the 100 Greatest Singles of All Time.
In 2003 German metal band Knorkator covered "Try Again" for their album Ich hasse Musik, turning the piece into a crushing orchestral industrial metal piece.
In December 2009, Rolling Stonemagazine listed the song 86th on their list of the 100 Best Songs of the Decade. On Billboard's hottest records of the 2000s list, the song placed 98th.

While promoting the movie Romeo Must Dieand the soundtrack of the film, Aaliyah performed this song on The Tonight Show with Jay Leno, The Rosie O'Donnell Show, Top of the Pops, MTV's Romeo Must Diespecial and Total Request Live.

The music video was filmed at Hollywood Center Studios in early March 2000. It begins with Jet Li entering a hall of mirrors and Aaliyah stepping in, wearing a revealing low-cut bra and tight low-rise leather pants. Timbaland is also shown. The making of the video and the video itself was featured on the Romeo Must DieDVD. The video was directed by Wayne Isham, with Fatima Robinson creating the choreography. The "Hall of Mirrors" room was inspired by Bruce Lee's Enter the Dragon. The video placed 7th on BET's year-end special Notarized: Top 100 Videos of 2000and ranks 46th on Channel Max's Top 100 Sexiest Women.

At the 43rd Grammy Awards, "Try Again" was nominated for Best Female R&B Vocal Performance. The single was also honored with two Soul Train Music Award nominations: Best R&B/Soul Single and R&B/Soul or Rap Music Video. "Try Again" won two MTV Video Music Awards for Best Female Video and Best Video from a Film.

"Try Again" debuted on the Billboard Hot 100 in mid-March 2000, eventually topping the chart on the week of June 17. It stayed in the top 10 for a massive fifteen weeks and in the top one hundred for thirty-two weeks. It also peaked at number one on the Billboard Hot 100 Airplay chart for nine weeks. On the year-end chart for Billboard Hot 100, it was ranked twelfth and ranked eighteenth on the Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs year-end chart.
On the UK Singles Chart, it debuted and peaked at number five, staying in the top 75 for 12 weeks.
It peaked at number 8 in Australia. It ranked 51st on the year-end chart of ARIA Charts.
In Germany, the song peaked at number five and remained in the chart for twenty weeks. The song became the 7th most successful song of Germany in 2000.
In France, the song reached the top 30.
This song was covered by the German heavy metal g roup Knorkator.A lo-fi cover version was also done by Danish musician Jesper Henriksen.
At the beginning of the song, Timbaland pays homage to Eric B. & Rakim's song "I Know You Got Soul" by rapping the line that opens the original song (with slight alterations):
"It's been a long time, I shouldn't have left you without a dope beat to step to."
The song was sampled by British popstar George Michael on his single "Freeek!".
